Rich S

messages.msgSnippet: Jim/John: Thanks very much for the comments! Jim, I appreciate you taking the time to provide the insight on the early guard. The pine tree guard is very
messages.messageBody:
Jim/John:

Thanks very much for the comments!
Jim, I appreciate you taking the time to provide the insight on the
early guard.

The pine tree guard is very unusual (to me). Unfortunately, the
photographs don't show it very well. It is primitive, but bold. I
did a scan that captured its "spirit" much better:
http://www.nihontophile.com/Sukashi3.jpg
A big, heavy guard..

Thanks very much,
Ron P.

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Jim Gilbert" <jggilbert@E...>
wrote:
> Ron,
> The first looks like a typical Kyo Shoami. Ito guards are usually
more naturalistically carved with more detail and sharper edges, and
the iron is a bit smoother textured. I find Bizen Shoami to be hard
to pin down sometimes, but most examples seem to be more heavily
decorated with inlay. Another possibility is Kinai. They did
occasionally do carving that looks a lot like Kyo Shoami and they
sometimes added inlay metal like that. Their metal usually has a
black finish and the seppa dai tend to be narrower. They also
signed their work more frequently than did the Kyo Shoami. Given
the alternatives, the design, carving, decoration and metal seem
most likely Kyo Shoami.
>
> The older guard almost looks Saotome, but it's at least in the
Katchushi vein. Given the raised rim and the position of the
sukashi, I don't see any sign of it having been cut down. Early
pieces sometimes have very eccentric hitsuana. The unusually large
openings were probably used with o-kozuka or o-kogai. There seem to
be more iron tsuba with large ana around today than there are the
kozuka or kogai they were mounted with at one time.
>
> I suspect that in this case the hitsuana, or at least that the
large one, are original or at least the same age as the openwork
design. Look at how the sukashi pattern is pushed much closer to
the rim on the side with the large opening vs. the side with the
small one. If the original design had no hitsuana, why create that
asymmetry in the sukashi pattern? It would be unbalanced even with
a "normal" sized kozuka ana, but the sukashi pattern is designed
with just enough room for each ana while keeping the impression of a
reasonably balanced design. From what I can see in the photo, I'd
guess that it's late Muromachi or possibly a bit older.
>
> Other thoughts?
> Jim

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] (unknown)
messages.msgSnippet: Ron, The first looks like a typical Kyo Shoami.  Ito guards are usually more naturalistically carved with more detail and sharper edges, and the iron is a bit
messages.messageBody:
Ron,
The first looks like a typical Kyo Shoami. Ito guards are usually more naturalistically carved with more detail and sharper edges, and the iron is a bit smoother textured. I find Bizen Shoami to be hard to pin down sometimes, but most examples seem to be more heavily decorated with inlay. Another possibility is Kinai. They did occasionally do carving that looks a lot like Kyo Shoami and they sometimes added inlay metal like that. Their metal usually has a black finish and the seppa dai tend to be narrower. They also signed their work more frequently than did the Kyo Shoami. Given the alternatives, the design, carving, decoration and metal seem most likely Kyo Shoami.

The older guard almost looks Saotome, but it's at least in the Katchushi vein. Given the raised rim and the position of the sukashi, I don't see any sign of it having been cut down. Early pieces sometimes have very eccentric hitsuana. The unusually large openings were probably used with o-kozuka or o-kogai. There seem to be more iron tsuba with large ana around today than there are the kozuka or kogai they were mounted with at one time.

I suspect that in this case the hitsuana, or at least that the large one, are original or at least the same age as the openwork design. Look at how the sukashi pattern is pushed much closer to the rim on the side with the large opening vs. the side with the small one. If the original design had no hitsuana, why create that asymmetry in the sukashi pattern? It would be unbalanced even with a "normal" sized kozuka ana, but the sukashi pattern is designed with just enough room for each ana while keeping the impression of a reasonably balanced design. From what I can see in the photo, I'd guess that it's late Muromachi or possibly a bit older.

Other thoughts?
Jim
----- Original Message -----


List:

I have a couple of tsuba I was wondering if the list would help me
with-
First one:
http://www.nihontophile.com/Sukashi1.jpg
http://www.nihontophile.com/Sukashi2.jpg
(nice heavy tsuba, 3 1/8")
I think Bizen Shoami or some school related to Bushu or Ito (I think
late Edo).
Any other ideas?

Second one:
http://www.nihontophile.com/KoKat1.jpg
http://www.nihontophile.com/KoKat2.jpg
(very thin, slightly under 3". purplish iron with remnants of lacquer
on the plate)
I think Ko-Katchushi. pre-Edo to Momoyama.
Is the kozuka ana original? It is huge...

Thanks for looking,
Ron P.



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] (unknown)
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Ron; I think you are correct on both calls.  First looks like a Bushu Ito and the second a cut down Katchushi.  The hitsu were usually put in later.  I have
messages.messageBody:
Hi Ron;

I think you are correct on both calls. First looks like a Bushu Ito and the second a cut down Katchushi. The hitsu were usually put in later. I have seen some of these large Kozuka hitsu in Momoyama and early Edo tsuba.

John
